review.title: Syntactic Analysis Based on Morphological Characteristic Features of the Romanian Language
review.abstract: This paper refers to the syntactic analysis of phrases in Romanian, as an important process of natural language processing. We will suggest a real-time solution, based on the idea of using some words or groups of words that indicate grammatical category; and some specific endings of some parts of sentence. Our idea is based on some characteristics of the Romanian language, where some prepositions, adverbs or some specific endings can provide a lot of information about the structure of a complex sentence. Such characteristics can be found in other languages, too, such as French. Using a special grammar, we developed a system (DIASEXP) that can perform a dialogue in natural language with assertive and interogative sentences about a "story" (a set of sentences describing some events from the real life).

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijnlc.2012.1401 1This paper refers to the syntactical analysis of phrases in Romanian as an important process of processing natural language. We propose a real-time solution based on the idea of using some words or groups of words that indicate grammatical categories; and some specific endings of some sentences. Our idea is based on some features of the Romanian language, in which prepositions, adverbs or certain endings can provide a lot of information about the structure of a complex sentence. Such features can also be found in other languages, such as French. Using a special grammar, we developed a system (DIASEXP) that can conduct a dialogue in natural language with self-confident and interogative sentences about a "story" (a series of sentences describing some real-life events).KEYWORDSNatural Language Processing, Syntactic Analysis, Morphology, Grammar, Romanian Language.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Before performing a semantic analysis of the natural language, we should define the lexicon and syntactic rules of a formal grammar that is useful in generating simple sentences in the respective language (e.g. English, French or Romanian). We will consider a simple grammar with some rules for the lexicon and some rules for the grammatical categories. The rules for the lexicon will be of type (1):

sections.text: where G is a grammatical category (or part of the language) and W is a word from a particular dictionary; the other syntactic rules are of type (2):

sections.heading: G1 → G2 G3 (2)
sections.text: This means that the first grammatical category (G1) is formed from the concatenation of the other two (G2 and G3) "intelligent" sentences, from the right side of the arrow. sections.heading: 2. USING THE DEFINITE CLAUSE GRAMMARS
sections.text: In order that our grammar does not generate false sentences in the nominative (subjective), we should use the terms of gender, number, case, etc., which indicate, for example, that "femeie" and "frumoasă" have the female gender and singular number. "El iubește ea" is wrong because "ea" is in the nominative case, and we should use the "pe" preposition to get the battery case. The correct formulation is "El iubește pe ea," or even "El o iubește pe ea." ("He loves it"). If we take the case into account, the grammar is no longer independent of the context: it is not true that every NP is the same, regardless of the context. Nevertheless, if we want to work with a grammar that is independent of the context, we can split the category NP into two, NPN and NPA to divide verbal groups in the nominjective (subjective), or categories (the two), respectively.

sections.heading: 4. DIASEXP
sections.text: Using the grammar from the previous section, we developed the DIASEXP system. DIASEXP has a simple text interface in which the user can introduce various expressions that describe some knowledge of some real events. This collection of expressions is recorded as a "story." However, each sentence of history is analyzed by the system, which automatically recognizes the parts of the sentence and inserts them into a table with the following fields: 1. Subject - this will represent the simple subject of the sentence (a noun or pronoun) (see rules 4 and 37 in Figure 3); 2. Attrib _ sub - this will be the attribute of the subject (it can be, for example, an adjective, see rules 9 and 12 in the same figure); 3. Predicate - the predicate of the sentence represents the main action of the self-conscious sentence; the predicate can be represented by a normal verb or the copulative verb "a fi."

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: CFG and DCG are types of generative grammars used in the syntactical analysis of a phrase in natural language. Sometimes, long or complex phrases pose a problem for classical chart parsers. Characteristics of the Romanian language, which are related to the morphology of words or the way adverbs are formed, can be successfully used in syntactical analysis by using a system based on patterns. This system works in real time and does not record the entire dictionary of Romanian language. It will use a small dictionary of "prefixes" (prepositions, adverbs, etc.) as well as some endings and linkages.
